data.text:
The classic â€œA Rugrats Passover,â€ which originally aired April 13, 1995, shockingly tells the story of Passover. It was one of the most popular episodes in the entirety of the Rugrats run, nominated for an Emmy, and Nickelodeonâ€™s first programming about Passover. As the New York Times wrote when the episode aired in 1995: â€œIf not a first, it certainly is a rarity: a cartoon series devoting an episode to a Jewish holy day.â€

In one word, A Rugrats Passover was ICONIC.

But we wanted to know how accurate this retelling of the Passover story actually is. Only 23 minutes, thereâ€™s a lot to cover.

The episode starts with Angelica in her carseat, putting jelly on matzah. Angelicaâ€™s family is on the way to Boris and Minkaâ€™s house (Tommyâ€™s grandparents), and Angelica is upset that theyâ€™re going, but her dad says, â€œAngelica, maybe youâ€™ll have fun. Passover is a very meaningful holiday.â€ And her mom explains to her that Passoverâ€™s about freedom.

Fact check #1: Passover is about freedom.

Verdict: Accurate. The gist of the Passover story is â€œonce we were slaves in Egypt, and now we are free.â€ Itâ€™s the tale of liberation of the Hebrews and their journey to Israel. As My Jewish Learning explains, â€œThis is the holiday that celebrates Godâ€™s intervention in history to lead the Israelites from slavery to freedom.â€

Then we see Tommy in the car with his parents. Stu (Tommyâ€™s Dad) is complaining that the seder is so boring. Didi refutes him, saying, â€œPassover isnâ€™t boring! Itâ€™s a very meaningful holidayâ€¦ the Passover seder is a time for Jewish families to come together and retell the history of their people. Weâ€™ve been doing it for thousands of years.â€

Fact check #2: The seder has happened for thousands of years.

Verdict: accurate. As My Jewish Learning explains in their article about Passover history, Passover observance has taken a number of forms throughout time. The first appearance of the Haggadah (the book used at seders) is found around 200 C.E. So Didi is right: The celebration of Passover and retelling the history of the Jewish people has happened for thousands of years.

Minka and Boris, in heavy accents, argue about whose wine glasses to use. Borisâ€™ fatherâ€™s came from Smolensk (in Russia), and Minkaâ€™s motherâ€™s came from Vilnius (Lithuania). Both these places had significant Jewish populations until the Holocaust.

This argument over wine glasses is going to be the start of the plot. Sidenote: There was a huge controversy over the design of Boris and Minka; in 1998, the ADL issued a statement saying their depictions were anti-Semitic and compared them to drawings from a 1930s Nazi newspaper.

Fact check #3: arguing over traditions.

Verdict: Yeah, weâ€™re going to go ahead and guess this happens in nearly every Jewish home around Passover.

Angelica and her parents arrive at Tommyâ€™s grandparents house. Angelica asks for a cookie, and is refused by her mom, who explains, â€œYou canâ€™t eat anything with bread.â€

Fact check #4: no bread on Passover.

Verdict: I think we all know this one. Accurate! During Passover, Jews avoid food made from leavened grain.

Tommyâ€™s family also arrives, and Tommyâ€™s grandma Minka starts crying that her husband ran away from her (over the aforementioned wine glass fight). They decide to go ahead with the seder anyway and finish prepping the foods. Stu gets to grind the gefilte fish.

Fact check #5: Gefilte fish is made by grinding fish.

Verdict: Semi-accurate. You typically want to remove the fins and scales from the fish before grinding, and here it seems like there is still a whole tail in the mix (gross!).

Plot update: Minka is still super upset about Boris. Angelica is looking for toys. Chuckie and his dad, Chas, arrive. Chas tells Didi, â€œIt was very nice of you to include Chuckie and me in the festivities tonight. Weâ€™re not really Jewish, you knowâ€¦ Actually, weâ€™re not really anything.â€

Fact check #6: including non-Jews at Passover.

Verdict: Accurate. Some Haggadahs include the line, â€œAnyone who is famished should come and eat, anyone who is in need should come and partake of the Pesach sacrifice.â€ Many Jewish families take this to mean including as many as possible in the seder.

Back to the plotâ€¦ Chuckie is disappointed by the lack of toys in Tommyâ€™s grandparentsâ€™ house. Tommy explains, â€œThey got better toys, Chuckie, only theyâ€™re all the way upstairs in the attic.â€ They try to â€œbust outâ€ of their playpen â€” except Tommy left his screwdriver in his other diaper! Gasp! Angelica lets them out of the playpen, because, â€œPassoverâ€™s all about freedom.â€

The three of them set off to the attic, while the adults sit down to the seder table.

Stu has to lead the seder because Boris is still MIA. The seder table seems to have all the key things: a seder plate, a glass for Elijah, matzah, and Haggadahs.

Fact check #7: whatâ€™s on the seder table.

Verdict: Accurate. It really seems like Rugrats has all its bases covered here. As My Jewish Learning writes, â€œThe seder plate (kâ€™arah), which serves as the centerpiece of the seder table. The seder plate traditionally holds five or six items.â€ Thereâ€™s also three pieces of matzah.

Meanwhileâ€¦ Tommy, Chuckie, and Angelica venture to the attic, where they find Tommyâ€™s grandpa Boris!

Fact check #8: the word kinderlach.

Verdict: Accurate. Itâ€™s a Yiddish word that means children.

They all get stuck in the attic because the door doesnâ€™t open from the inside. Angelica reassures Grandpa Boris that heâ€™s not missing anything â€™cause itâ€™s a dumb holiday, but Grandpa Boris, indignant, tells her itâ€™s the best holiday.

Fact check #9: Passover is the greatest.

Verdict: Unclear. This is a very subjective statement, after all.

We go back down to the adultsâ€™ seder, where Didi reprimands Stu for not using enough emotion while reading the Haggadah. Chuckieâ€™s dad goes to check on the kids and discovers them missing.

But back to Boris and the kids, more important. Boris begins the story of Passoverâ€¦

Boris tells the kids, â€œMany thousands of years ago, there a lived a people called the Egyptians. They were very powerful and built all kinds of beautiful cities and buildings. But there also lived in Egypt the Jewish people, the Hebrews. At first, they all lived happily together, side by sideâ€¦ Now, the Egyptian Pharaohâ€¦ the Pharaoh, he was kinda of like a king. And this Pharaoh person decided all the Hebrews had to be slaves of the Egyptians. He made them pull heavy stones, and work in the hot sun, and do whatever else he wanted.â€

Fact check #10: The Egyptians and Hebrews used to live in peace.

Verdict: Accurate. Remember Joseph (And the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat)? The Hebrews ended up in Egypt after a long chain of events, where they lived side by side with the Egyptians.

Fact check #11: Pharaoh decides to enslave the Hebrews.

Verdict: Accurate. Exodus 1:8 â€“ 13 says, â€œA new king arose over Egypt who did not know Joseph. And he said to his people, â€˜Look, the Israelite people are much too numerous for usâ€¦..â€™ So they set taskmasters over them to oppress them with forced labor; and they built garrison cities for Pharaoh: Pithom and Raamses.â€

Fact check #12: heavy stones and hot sun.

Verdict: Accurate. Exodus 1:13 â€“ 14 says, â€œThe Egyptians ruthlessly imposed upon the Israelites the various labors that they made them perform. Ruthlessly they made life bitter for them with harsh labor at mortar and bricks and with all sorts of tasks in the field.â€ Boris ğŸ‘ knows ğŸ‘ his ğŸ‘ ExodusğŸ‘ storyğŸ‘.

Boris continues the story, â€œOne day, it was foretold that a leader of the Hebrew people would rise up and overthrow the Pharaoh. The Pharaoh was very worried, so he told the Hebrews to throw all their boy babies in the Nile river.â€

Fact check #13: prophecy about a Hebrew leader overthrowing the Pharaoh.

Verdict: False. This isnâ€™t really the order of events. Pharaoh is frustrated by how much the Israelites kept growing through reproduction, not worried about a future leader.

Fact check #14: telling Hebrews to throw their boys thrown in the Nile.

Verdict: Accurate-ish. At first, Pharaoh doesnâ€™t tell the Hebrews as a whole, he tells two Hebrew midwives (who are badass), Shiphrah and Puah, to kill Hebrew baby boys. They donâ€™t listen to Pharaoh because they feared God. After the midwives donâ€™t work, Pharaoh, according to Exodus 1:22, â€œcharged all his people, saying, â€˜Every boy that is born you shall throw into the Nile, but let every girl live.'â€

The story continues: â€œOne of the slave women decided to save her baby by putting him in a basket and sending him down the river.â€

Fact check #15: Hebrew woman sends her baby in a basket down the Nile.

Verdict: Accurate. This is Mosesâ€™ mom, Yocheved, who defied the Egyptians and sent her baby down the river. (Are you singing Ofra Hazaâ€™s â€œRiver Lullabyâ€ from The Prince of Egypt in your head right now? Cause same.)

After Moses gets sent down the Nile, Boris says, â€œThe Pharaoh was floating by on the royal bargeâ€ and discovers the baby in the bushes and took him to the royal palace.

Fact check #16: Pharaoh discovers the baby.

Verdict: False. Pharaohâ€™s daughter actually discovers the baby. As Rishe Groner explains in â€œThe Badass Biblical Women of Passover,â€ â€œBatya was a fearless priestess princess who didnâ€™t care what people said: She was adopting this baby, and Moses would be her son, no matter what the Egyptian priests, astrologers, and her dad the king said.â€

At this point in â€œA Rugrats Passoverâ€ (you still with us?), Tommy, Chuckie, and Angelica are reenacting the story, so it gets a little wonky. Pharaoh (Angelica) asks Moses (Tommy) to help run Egypt. Boris explains, â€œPharaoh didnâ€™t know Moses was a Hebrew.â€

Fact check #17: Pharaoh asks Moses to help run Egypt.

Verdict: Accurate-ish. Moses is raised as part of the royal family, so itâ€™s assumed that Pharaoh trusted Moses with the affairs of the country. (At least, The Prince of Egypt thinks so.)

Fact check #18: Pharaoh didnâ€™t know Moses was a Hebrew.

Verdict: Unsure. We donâ€™t really know what Pharaoh knew about Moses, but Exodus 2:6 says Pharaohâ€™s daughter knew the baby was a Hebrew child.

At this point in the story, Chuckieâ€™s dad finds them in the attic and gets stuck with them. Boris continues the story. â€œPharaoh made Moses his helper. Then one day, Moses was watching the Hebrews as they built a new city for Pharaoh.â€

And we flash back to the baby version of Egypt â€” where Tommy/Moses sees the babies pushing blocks around. Heâ€™s confused, asking them why theyâ€™re not allowed to have fun because heâ€™s a baby and Pharaoh lets him have fun.

Okay, keeping with the internal logic that babies = Hebrewsâ€¦

Fact check #19: Moses knew he was a Hebrew, and was confused why Hebrews were enslaved.

Verdict: We donâ€™t know. Itâ€™s not explicit in the text whether or not Moses knew he was a Hebrew, but he lived happily as an Egyptian.

An Egyptian overseer pushes Chuckie (a baby) and Moses/Tommy gets mad, telling him, â€œYou canâ€™t treat babies like that,â€ and pushes the Egyptian. The babies warn Moses/Tommy heâ€™s going to get in trouble once Pharaoh finds out heâ€™s a baby. Chuckie tells Moses/Tommy, â€œMoses, I think you better get out of here.â€

Fact check #20: Moses confronts an Egyptian he sees beating a Hebrew.

Verdict: Accurate. According to Exodus 2:11-12, â€œWhen Moses had grown upâ€¦ He saw an Egyptian beating a Hebrew, one of his kinsmen. He turned this way and that and, seeing no one about, he struck down the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.â€

Fact check #21: Moses flees.

Verdict: Accurate. After killing an Egyptian, Moses flees to Midian, aka the desert.

Fact check #22: Moses becomes a shepherd, and forgets all about Egypt.

Verdict: Accurate-ish. He becomes a shepherd, marries Tzipporah, but Exodus never really says anything about him forgetting Egypt.

Boris continues the story: Moses was out one day and saw a burning bush. The bush spoke to him and told Moses he must return to Egypt and â€œdemand that Pharaoh stop making his people slaves.â€

Fact check #23: God comes to Moses in a burning bush and tells him to return to Egypt to lead the Hebrews out of slavery.

Verdict: Accurate. God tells Moses in Exodus 3:10, â€œI will send you to Pharaoh, and you shall free My people, the Israelites, from Egypt.â€

Then in the baby-version of the Exodus story, we see delegations from Ethiopia, China, and Persia bringing Pharaoh gifts. Then Moses/Tommy appears, telling Pharaoh, â€œLet my babies go!â€ Pharaoh remains unconvinced, so Moses/Tommy warns Pharaoh that â€œscary things will happen,â€ and his rod turns into a snake. Pharaoh is unconvinced, saying itâ€™s just a magic trick and that they can do magic too (cue up â€œPlaying with the Big Boysâ€ from Prince of Egypt).

Fact check #24: Moses returns to Pharaoh and tells him, â€œLet my people go!â€

Verdict: Accurate. DAYENU!

Fact check #25: Pharaoh is unconvinced.

Verdict: Yep.

Fact check #26: To prove himself, Mosesâ€™ rod turns into a serpent.

Verdict: Kinda accurate. Itâ€™s not Mosesâ€™ rod, but Aaronâ€™s. Exodus 7:10 says, â€œSo Moses and Aaron came before Pharaoh and did just as the LORD had commanded: Aaron cast down his rod in the presence of Pharaoh and his courtiers, and it turned into a serpent.â€

Fact check #27: Pharaoh says Egyptians can do magic, too.

Verdict: Accurate. After Aaronâ€™s rod turns into a serpent, Pharaoh summons Egyptian magicians and they turn their rods into serpents. Then Aaronâ€™s rod-serpent swallows their rod-serpents.

Back to Borisâ€™ narration, where he says the plagues are: frogs, lice, darkness, wild beasts, locusts. And after that, Boris explains, Pharaoh says the Hebrews could go.

Fact check #28: Moses unleashes five plagues, and the Hebrews prepare to leave.

Verdict: False. There were 10 plagues: Blood, Frogs, Lice, Flies, Pestilence, Boils, Hail, Locusts, Darkness, and Killing of the firstborn.

As Wikipedia points out, â€œThe writers were forced to audit many elements of the portrayal of the Ten Plagues, particularly the last one, so that the episode would remain accessible to children and not too frightening.â€

So, Boris explains, the Hebrews prepare to leave Egypt, when the Pharaoh changes his mind.

Fact check #29: Pharaoh decides the Hebrews arenâ€™t allowed to leave.

Verdict: Not quite. In Exodus, they do leave before Pharaoh changes his mind.

Butâ€¦ maybe thatâ€™s Pharaoh rejecting Mosesâ€™s plea after the initial plagues. Because, Boris now explains, thereâ€™s â€œone final plague, more terrible than all the others. He announced that the firstborn of every Egyptian household would be taken away.â€

Fact check #30: The final plague was the killing of the firstborn.

Verdict: Accurate.

Pharaoh/Angelica, after hearing Mosesâ€™ threat, calls her dad and asks if sheâ€™s the firstborn. After learning she is, she realizes sheâ€™s in trouble.

Fact check #31: Pharaoh worries heâ€™s going to die from the 10th plague.

Verdict: False. Pharaoh is spared, but his first-born is killed.

Fact check #32: Hebrews are protected from the plague by a red mark.

Verdict: Accurate. While not explicit, this represents the Hebrews painting their doorposts with lambâ€™s blood so their firstborn are not killed.

Pharaoh goes to Moses/Tommy and tells him they can go if they â€œcall off this firstborn thing.â€

Fact check #33: The Hebrews leave cause they call off the 10th plague.

Verdict: False. They leave after Pharaoh and all of Egypt is hurt by the 10th plague.

And so: The babies leave Egypt! With flat bread, because Chuckie forgot to put yeast in the bread. But hey, Chuckie invented matzah!

Fact check #34: Matzah was invented because they forgot yeast.

Verdict: False. Matzah/unleavened bread was because the Hebrews rushed out of Egypt and didnâ€™t have time for their bread to rise.

Pharaoh has second thoughts about letting the Hebrews go, so he pursues them in a chariot with the rest of the Egyptians.

Fact check #35: Pharaoh and the Egyptians pursue the Hebrews.

Verdict: Accurate. Exodus 14:5 says, â€œWhen the king of Egypt was told that the people had fled, Pharaoh and his courtiers had a change of heart about the people and said, â€˜What is this we have done, releasing Israel from our service?'â€

Boris wraps up the story: â€œNow, the Hebrews were at the edge of the Red Sea with the ocean in front of them and Pharaohâ€™s army behindâ€¦â€ And so Moses parts the Red Sea, and they make it to the other side, and the water closes in on the pursuing Egyptian army.

Fact check #36: Moses parts the Red Sea so the Hebrews can escape the Egyptian army and Pharaoh.

Verdict: Accurate. Iconic.

And the Hebrews make it to freedom.

Fact check #37: Moses leads the Hebrews to freedom.

Verdict: Accurate.

We gotta give it to you, Rugrats: You did good.

Happy Passover!
